“There are one or two minor points which were brought out in the inquest, and which are worth considering.”

“What are they?” I asked.

“It appears,” said Holmes, “that his arrest did not take place at once, but after the return to Hatherley Farm. On the inspector of constabulary informing him that he was a prisoner, he remarked that he was not surprised to hear it, and that it was no more than his deserts. This observation of his had the natural effect of removing any traces of doubt which might have remained in the minds of the coroner’s jury.”

“It was a confession,” I ejaculated.

“No, for it was followed by a protestation of innocence.”

“Coming on the top of such a damning series of events, it was at least a most suspicious remark.”

“On the contrary,” said Holmes, “it is the brightest rift which I can at present see in the clouds. However innocent he might be, he could not be such an absolute imbecile as not to see that the circumstances were very black against him. Had he appeared surprised at his own arrest, or feigned indignation at it, I should have looked upon it as highly suspicious, because such surprise or anger would not be natural under the circumstances, and yet might appear to be the best policy to a scheming man. His frank acceptance of the situation marks him as either an innocent man, or else as a man of considerable self-restraint and firmness. As to his remark about his deserts, it was also not unnatural if you consider that he stood beside the dead body of his father, and that there is no doubt that he had that very day so far forgotten his filial duty as to bandy words with him, and even, according to the little girl whose evidence is so important, to raise his hand as if to strike him. The self-reproach and contrition which are displayed in his remark appear to me to be the signs of a healthy mind rather than of a guilty one.”

I shook my head. “Many men have been hanged on far slighter evidence,” I remarked.

“So they have. And many men have been wrongfully hanged.”

“What is the young man’s own account of the matter?”

“It is, I am afraid, not very encouraging to his supporters, though there are one or two points in it which are suggestive. You will find it here, and may read it for yourself.”

He picked out from his bundle a copy of the local Herefordshire paper, and having turned down the sheet he pointed out the paragraph in which the unfortunate young man had given his own statement of what had occurred. I settled myself down in the corner of the carriage and read it very carefully. It ran in this way:

“Mr. James McCarthy, the only son of the deceased, was then called and gave evidence as follows:—‘I had been away from home for three days at Bristol, and had only just returned upon the morning of last Monday, the 3rd. My father was absent from home at the time of my arrival, and I was informed by the maid that he had driven over to Ross with John Cobb, the groom. Shortly after my return I heard the wheels of his trap in the yard, and, looking out of my window, I saw him get out and walk rapidly out of the yard, though I was not aware in which direction he was going. I then took my gun and strolled out in the direction of the Boscombe Pool, with the intention of visiting the rabbit warren which is upon the other side. On the way I saw William Crowder, the game-keeper, as he has stated in his evidence, but he is mistaken in thinking that I was following my father. I had no idea that he was in front of me. When about a hundred yards from the pool I heard a cry of “Cooee!” which was a usual signal between my father and myself. I then hurried forward, and found him standing by the pool. He appeared to be surprised to see me and asked me rather roughly what I was doing there. A conversation ensued which led to high words and almost to blows, for my father was a man of a very violent temper. Seeing that his passion was becoming ungovernable, I left him and returned towards Hatherley Farm. I had not gone more than 150 yards, however, when I heard a hideous outcry behind me, which caused me to run back again. I found my father expiring upon the ground, with his head terribly injured. I dropped my gun and held him in my arms, but he could not say anything except some few incoherent words. I left him and ran towards the nearest house for help. I returned with the game-keeper, Crowder, and Dr. Willows, but my father was quite dead.’

“Did your father say anything to you before he died?”

“He mumbled a few words, but I could only catch some allusion to a rat.”

“What did you understand by that?”

“I thought that he was delirious.”

“What was the point upon which you and your father had this final quarrel?”

“I should prefer not to answer.”

“I am afraid that I must press it.”

“It is really impossible for me to tell you. I can assure you that it has nothing to do with the sad tragedy which followed.”

“That is for the court to decide. I need not point out to you that your refusal to answer will prejudice your case considerably in any future proceedings which may arise.”

“I cannot help that.”

“Was there any one else in the wood besides you and your father?”

“No one as far as I know.”

“Did you see any one or hear any one?”

“No.”

“A juryman: Did you not see something running away as you returned from the pool?”

“No, I saw nothing.”

“Was there no one in sight then?”

“No one.”

“Thanks.”

The Coroner: “What did you mean by your remark about a rat?”

The Witness: “I repeated that I could make nothing of it.”

The Coroner: “Did you see anything at all strange—any object or any person near the pool when you returned?”

The Witness: “Nothing definite.”

The Coroner: “What do you mean?”

The Witness: “I was so disturbed and excited as I rushed out of the wood that I hardly knew what I was doing. I seem to remember, however, that as I ran forward, I glanced to the left and saw something grey lying on the ground a short distance from the body, but I cannot say what it was. I only know that it was gone when I returned.”

The Coroner: “How far from the body?”

The Witness: “A dozen yards or so.”

The Coroner: “And how far from the edge of the wood?”

The Witness: “About the same.”

“Then if it was removed it must have been while you were within a dozen yards of it?”

“Yes, but I do not know that it was removed.”

“In the midst of the evidence, the coroner made some severe remarks upon the conduct of the accused, and pointed out the various discrepancies in his statement, as well as the refusal to state the cause of the quarrel, the allusion to a rat, and the impression of something grey which had vanished. All these were considered as points against him.”

Holmes laughed softly to himself and stretched himself out upon the cushioned seat. “You see, Watson,” he remarked, “our little problem draws to a close. I am afraid that the coroner and the jury have been a little too much for our young friend, but I am not convinced. I shall take the liberty of assuming that his statement is true, and see where that assumption leads us. And now, my dear Watson, let us for a time turn our attention to a less momentous matter. I have a note here from Mrs. Cecil Forrester, who would be glad if we would lunch with her at Swindon. She is a most charming woman, and I think that we may pass the time very pleasantly until we reach our destination.”

In the first place, I should like to ask you whether you have observed anything which may account for the dog’s strange behaviour on the night of the tragedy?”

The question seemed to puzzle the inspector. “I can’t say that I have, Mr. Holmes. The dog was always a quiet animal, and I never heard of its showing any signs of violence before.”

“Was it in the habit of barking at strangers?”

“Never, sir. It was as gentle as a lamb with everyone.”

Holmes leaned back in his chair, his eyes half closed, and his long, thin fingers pressed together. “It is curious,” he remarked, “very curious. You will remember, Watson, that the evidence at the inquest showed that the dog was found crouching beside the body, whining piteously, but that there was no sign of any struggle or of the animal having attempted to defend its master.”

“That is so,” I replied. “It was mentioned by several witnesses.”

“Now, if the dog had been in the habit of attacking strangers, or even of barking at them, we might have supposed that it had been silenced by the murderer. But if, as you say, it was always gentle, then its behaviour on that night becomes all the more remarkable. It is as if it had recognised the intruder, or at least had not regarded him as a stranger.”

The inspector nodded thoughtfully. “That is a point, Mr. Holmes. I had not considered it in that light.”

“There is another point,” Holmes continued. “The evidence showed that the window of the study was open, and that there were marks on the sill as if someone had entered or left by that means. Yet the ground beneath the window was soft, and there were no footprints.”

“That is true, sir. We examined it carefully.”

“Then we must suppose that the person who entered or left by the window did so with great care, or else that the marks were made by someone inside the room.”

The inspector looked perplexed. “It is a puzzling case, Mr. Holmes, and no mistake.”

Holmes smiled. “It is, indeed. But I have a theory which may account for some of these peculiarities. I should like to visit the scene of the crime, if you have no objection.”

“None at all, sir. I shall be glad of your assistance.”

“Then let us lose no time. Come, Watson, we have work to do.”

We set out at once for the house where the tragedy had occurred. It was a gloomy, old-fashioned building, standing in its own grounds, and surrounded by a high wall. The study, where the murder had taken place, was a small room at the back of the house, with a single window opening on to the garden.

Holmes examined the window carefully. “You see, Watson,” he said, “the marks on the sill are quite distinct. But there are no corresponding marks on the ground outside. That suggests that the window was opened from within, and that the marks were made by someone inside the room.”

He turned to the inspector. “Was anything missing from the room?”

“Nothing, sir. Everything was in its place.”

“And the door was locked on the inside?”

“Yes, sir. We had to break it open.”

Holmes nodded. “That is significant. It suggests that the murderer was someone whom the victim knew and admitted willingly, or else that he had a key.”

The inspector looked impressed. “You have a wonderful way of putting things, Mr. Holmes.”

Holmes smiled. “It is merely a matter of observation and deduction. Now, let us see if we can find any further clues.”

He examined the carpet, the furniture, and the fireplace with the utmost care, but found nothing to throw light on the mystery. At last he turned to the inspector. “I should like to see the dog,” he said.

The animal was brought in, a large, handsome retriever, with a gentle expression in its eyes. Holmes patted it kindly, and it wagged its tail in response.

“You see, Watson,” he said, “there is nothing savage about this creature. It is as gentle as a child. Yet on the night of the murder it was found crouching beside the body, whining piteously. That suggests that it was frightened, not by the presence of a stranger, but by something else.”

He turned to the inspector. “Has the dog shown any signs of fear or excitement since the tragedy?”

“None at all, sir. It has been perfectly quiet.”

Holmes nodded. “That is as I expected. The dog was not alarmed by the murderer, but by something else—perhaps by the suddenness of the crime, or by the sight of its master lying dead.”

He turned to me. “What do you think, Watson?”

“I think you are right, Holmes. The dog’s behaviour is easily explained if we suppose that it was frightened by the tragedy itself, and not by the presence of a stranger.”

“Exactly. And that brings us back to the question of the window. If the murderer did not enter or leave by the window, then he must have come in by the door. And if the door was locked on the inside, then he must have had a key, or else have been admitted by the victim.”

The inspector looked thoughtful. “That narrows the field, Mr. Holmes. There are only a few people who had keys to the house.”

“Precisely. And if we can find out who those people were, and what their movements were on the night of the crime, we may be able to solve the mystery.”

We spent the rest of the day making inquiries among the servants and the members of the household. It soon became clear that only three people had keys to the house: the victim himself, his brother, and the housekeeper. The brother had been away from home on the night of the murder, and the housekeeper had been in her own room, which was at the other end of the house.

Holmes questioned them both closely, but could find nothing to arouse his suspicions. At last he turned to me with a sigh. “It is a most perplexing case, Watson. There are one or two minor points which are worth considering, but the main facts seem to defy explanation.”

“Perhaps something will turn up,” I suggested.

Holmes smiled. “Perhaps. In the meantime, we must keep our eyes and ears open, and be ready to act when the opportunity arises.”

We returned to Baker Street late that evening, tired and disappointed. But Holmes was not discouraged. “We have made some progress, Watson,” he said. “We have eliminated several possibilities, and we have narrowed the field of inquiry. That is always something.”

He sat down at his desk and began to make notes in his notebook. I watched him in silence, marvelling at his patience and his powers of deduction. At last he looked up.

“There is one point which still puzzles me, Watson,” he said. “The behaviour of the dog. It is the key to the whole mystery, I am sure of it. If we can only understand what frightened the animal, we shall be on the right track.”

I nodded. “It is certainly a curious point.”

Holmes smiled. “Curious, but not inexplicable. I have a theory, Watson, and I mean to test it. But first, I must make a few inquiries. Will you come with me?”

“Of course, Holmes. Where are we going?”

“To the house of the victim’s brother. I have a suspicion that he may be able to throw some light on the matter.”

We set out at once, and soon arrived at the brother’s house. He received us politely, but seemed nervous and ill at ease. Holmes questioned him closely about his movements on the night of the murder, and about his relations with the victim. He answered all our questions readily, but I could not help feeling that he was concealing something.

At last Holmes rose to go. “Thank you for your courtesy,” he said. “I may have to trouble you again.”

The brother bowed, and we took our leave. As soon as we were outside, Holmes turned to me.

“Well, Watson, what do you think?”

“I think he is hiding something, Holmes.”

“So do I. And I mean to find out what it is. Come, let us return to Baker Street. I have work to do.”

For the next two days Holmes was busy with his investigations. He visited the house several times, questioned the servants, and examined the scene of the crime with the utmost care. At last he announced that he was ready to act.

“Watson,” he said, “I have solved the mystery. The key to the whole case lies in the behaviour of the dog. Come, and I will show you how it was done.”

We set out once more for the house. Holmes led the way to the study, and pointed to the window.

“You see, Watson, the marks on the sill were made by the dog, not by the murderer. The animal jumped up in its excitement, and left the marks with its paws. That is why there were no footprints outside.”

I stared at him in amazement. “But the door was locked on the inside. How did the murderer escape?”

Holmes smiled. “He did not escape. He was never in the room at all. The murder was committed from outside the window. The victim was sitting at his desk, with his back to the window. The murderer crept up in the darkness, and shot him through the open window. Then he closed the window, and the dog, in its excitement, jumped up and left the marks on the sill.”

I gasped. “But who was the murderer?”

Holmes’s eyes gleamed. “The brother. He had a motive, and he had the opportunity. He was not at home on the night of the murder, as he claimed. He was here, in the garden, waiting for his chance. He knew that his brother always sat at his desk at that hour, and he took advantage of the open window to commit the crime.”

The inspector, who had been listening in silence, nodded. “It fits the facts, Mr. Holmes. I will have him arrested at once.”

Holmes smiled. “You will find that he cannot account for his movements on the night of the murder. And you will find the weapon hidden in his room.”

The case was soon brought to a conclusion. The brother was arrested, and the evidence against him was overwhelming. He confessed to the crime, and was brought to justice.

As we left the house, Holmes turned to me with a smile. “You see, Watson, it is always the little things that are most important. The behaviour of the dog was the key to the whole mystery.”

I nodded. “You were right, Holmes. As always.”

And so another case was added to the long list of Holmes’s triumphs, and I was once more reminded of the extraordinary powers of observation and deduction which made him the greatest detective of his age.

detailed_summary: Holmes and Watson arrive in Ross around 4 PM.
They are met by Lestrade, disguised in country attire.
They proceed to the Hereford Arms hotel.
Lestrade mentions he ordered a carriage, expecting Holmes's eagerness to visit the crime scene immediately.
Holmes declines, citing the favorable barometric pressure (implying good weather for preservation of clues) and his preference to rest and smoke rather than rush.
Lestrade assumes Holmes has already solved the case from newspapers, calling it 'plain as a pikestaff,' but acknowledges Miss Turner insisted on Holmes's involvement.
Miss Turner arrives unexpectedly, rushing into the room in great distress.
Identifying Holmes, she expresses gladness at his arrival and passionately asserts James McCarthy's innocence, urging Holmes to believe it implicitly.
She states that knowing James since childhood, she's aware of his faults but insists he is too kind-hearted to commit such a crime.
Holmes promises to do all he can.
Miss Turner asks if Holmes sees any flaws in the evidence or thinks James is innocent; Holmes replies it's 'very probable.'
She reacts triumphantly towards Lestrade, who cautions Holmes against forming conclusions too quickly.
Miss Turner insists Holmes is right and reveals the quarrel between James and his father likely involved her.
She explains Mr. McCarthy desperately wanted her to marry James, but both she and James viewed each other as siblings, and James wasn't ready for marriage.
She confirms her own father, Mr. Turner, was also against the union.
Holmes inquires about seeing Mr. Turner, but Miss Turner says he is gravely ill, broken down by the tragedy, confined to bed with a shattered nervous system.
She adds that Mr. McCarthy was the only living person who knew her father from his time in Victoria.
Holmes seizes on the Victoria connection, confirming Mr. Turner made his money there, specifically at the gold mines.
Miss Turner thanks Holmes, asks for news, and requests he tell James she believes in his innocence.
She departs quickly to care for her ill father.

events.text_segment:
It was nearly four o’clock when we at last, after passing through the beautiful Stroud Valley, and over the broad gleaming Severn, found ourselves at the pretty little country-town of Ross. A lean, ferret-like man, furtive and sly-looking, was waiting for us upon the platform. In spite of the light brown dustcoat and leather-leggings which he wore in deference to his rustic surroundings, I had no difficulty in recognising Lestrade, of Scotland Yard. With him we drove to the Hereford Arms where a room had already been engaged for us.
“I have ordered a carriage,” said Lestrade as we sat over a cup of tea. “I knew your energetic nature, and that you would not be happy until you had been on the scene of the crime.”
“It was very nice and complimentary of you,” Holmes answered. “It is entirely a question of barometric pressure.”
Lestrade looked startled. “I do not quite follow,” he said.
“How is the glass? Twenty-nine, I see. No wind, and not a cloud in the sky. I have a caseful of cigarettes here which need smoking, and the sofa is very much superior to the usual country hotel abomination. I do not think that it is probable that I shall use the carriage to-night.”
Lestrade laughed indulgently. “You have, no doubt, already formed your conclusions from the newspapers,” he said. “The case is as plain as a pikestaff, and the more one goes into it the plainer it becomes. Still, of course, one can’t refuse a lady, and such a very positive one, too. She has heard of you, and would have your opinion, though I repeatedly told her that there was nothing which you could do which I had not already done. Why, bless my soul! here is her carriage at the door.”
He had hardly spoken before there rushed into the room one of the most lovely young women that I have ever seen in my life. Her violet eyes shining, her lips parted, a pink flush upon her cheeks, all thought of her natural reserve lost in her overpowering excitement and concern.
“Oh, Mr. Sherlock Holmes!” she cried, glancing from one to the other of us, and finally, with a woman’s quick intuition, fastening upon my companion, “I am so glad that you have come. I have driven down to tell you so. I know that James didn’t do it. I know it, and I want you to start upon your work knowing it, too. Never let yourself doubt upon that point. We have known each other since we were little children, and I know his faults as no one else does; but he is too tender-hearted to hurt a fly. Such a charge is absurd to anyone who really knows him.”
“I hope we may clear him, Miss Turner,” said Sherlock Holmes. “You may rely upon my doing all that I can.”
“But you have read the evidence. You have formed some conclusion? Do you not see some loophole, some flaw? Do you not yourself think that he is innocent?”
“I think that it is very probable.”
“There, now!” she cried, throwing back her head and looking defiantly at Lestrade. “You hear! He gives me hopes.”
Lestrade shrugged his shoulders. “I am afraid that my colleague has been a little quick in forming his conclusions,” he said.
“But he is right. Oh! I know that he is right. James never did it. And about his quarrel with his father, I am sure that the reason why he would not speak about it to the coroner was because I was concerned in it.”
“In what way?” asked Holmes.
“It is no time for me to hide anything. James and his father had many disagreements about me. Mr. McCarthy was very anxious that there should be a marriage between us. James and I have always loved each other as brother and sister; but of course he is young and has seen very little of life yet, and—and—well, he naturally did not wish to do anything like that yet. So there were quarrels, and this, I am sure, was one of them.”
“And your father?” asked Holmes. “Was he in favour of such a union?”
“No, he was averse to it also. No one but Mr. McCarthy was in favour of it.” A quick blush passed over her fresh young face as Holmes shot one of his keen, questioning glances at her.
“Thank you for this information,” said he. “May I see your father if I call to-morrow?”
“I am afraid the doctor won’t allow it.”
“The doctor?”
“Yes, have you not heard? Poor father has never been strong for years back, but this has broken him down completely. He has taken to his bed, and Dr. Willows says that he is a wreck and that his nervous system is shattered. Mr. McCarthy was the only man alive who had known dad in the old days in Victoria.”
“Ha! In Victoria! That is important.”
“Yes, at the mines.”
“Quite so; at the gold-mines, where, as I understand, Mr. Turner made his money.”
“Yes, certainly.”
“Thank you, Miss Turner. You have been of material assistance to me.”
“You will tell me if you have any news to-morrow. No doubt you will go to the prison to see James. Oh, if you do, Mr. Holmes, do tell him that I know him to be innocent.”
“I will, Miss Turner.”
“I must go home now, for dad is very ill, and he misses me so if I leave him. Good-bye, and God help you in your undertaking.” She hurried from the room as impulsively as she had entered, and we heard the wheels of her carriage rattle off down the street.

Holmes, who had been silent for much of the journey, now roused himself and looked about with keen interest as the train drew up at the small station. We alighted, and our luggage was quickly transferred to a waiting fly, which was to convey us to the residence of Dr. Mortimer, whose letter had so urgently summoned us from London.

Presently, we turned into a gravelled drive, at the end of which stood a modest but comfortable-looking house, half-covered in climbing roses.

Dr. Mortimer himself met us at the door, a tall, thin man with a gentle, scholarly air. He greeted us warmly, though his manner was tinged with a certain nervousness, as though the burden of his mysterious problem weighed heavily upon him.

"Mr. Holmes, Dr. Watson, I cannot tell you how grateful I am that you have come," he said, ushering us into a cosy sitting-room. "The matter is of the utmost urgency, and I fear that every hour may be of consequence."

Holmes seated himself in an armchair, steepling his fingers and regarding our host with his usual air of quiet concentration. "Pray, Dr. Mortimer, let us come at once to the point. You spoke in your letter of a singular occurrence which has greatly disturbed you."

Dr. Mortimer nodded, and after a moment's hesitation, he produced a folded document from his pocket. "It is this, Mr. Holmes. I received it three days ago, and since then I have scarcely known a moment's peace."

He handed the paper to Holmes, who unfolded it and examined it closely. It was a sheet of plain, unmarked paper, upon which a few words had been printed in rough, uneven characters:

"If you value your life or your reason, keep away from the moor."

Holmes read the message aloud, then turned it over in his hands. "There is no signature, no indication of the sender?"

"None whatever. It was delivered by the morning post, and the envelope bore the Ross postmark."

Holmes nodded thoughtfully. "And what, may I ask, is the significance of the moor in this context?"

Dr. Mortimer hesitated, glancing nervously at the window as though half-expecting to see some shadowy figure lurking outside. "The moor, Mr. Holmes, is the scene of the recent tragedy which has so unsettled us all. It was there that Sir Charles Baskerville met his untimely end."

At the mention of the name, Holmes's eyes gleamed with interest. "Ah, yes, the Baskerville case. I have read something of it in the papers. A most peculiar affair."

"Peculiar indeed," said Dr. Mortimer gravely. "Sir Charles was a man of robust constitution, yet he was found dead upon the path leading to the old yew alley, his features contorted in an expression of the utmost terror. The coroner returned a verdict of death from natural causes, but there are those who believe that something more sinister was at work."

Holmes leaned forward, his interest evidently aroused. "You yourself, Dr. Mortimer, do you share that belief?"

Dr. Mortimer hesitated. "I am a man of science, Mr. Holmes, and yet I cannot dismiss the strange circumstances which attended Sir Charles's death. There were footprints—footprints of a gigantic hound—found near the body. And then there is the legend of the Baskerville family, which has cast a shadow over the house for generations."

Holmes smiled faintly. "You refer, I presume, to the story of the spectral hound which is said to haunt the moor?"

"Precisely. I know it sounds fantastic, but the people here believe it implicitly. And now, with this warning, I fear that the danger is not yet past. Sir Henry Baskerville, the heir, is due to arrive from Canada, and I dread to think what may befall him if he takes up residence at Baskerville Hall."

Holmes was silent for a moment, his gaze fixed upon the cryptic message. At length he spoke. "You have done wisely in consulting me, Dr. Mortimer. There are certainly elements in this case which call for the most careful investigation. I shall be pleased to place myself at your disposal."

Dr. Mortimer's face brightened. "Thank you, Mr. Holmes. I feel sure that with your help we may yet avert a tragedy."

Holmes rose and paced the room, his hands clasped behind his back. "There are several points which require clarification. First, the nature of the warning. It is clearly intended to frighten Sir Henry away from the moor. Second, the circumstances of Sir Charles's death, and the evidence of the hound. Third, the legend itself, and its possible bearing upon the present situation."

He turned to Dr. Mortimer. "I should like to visit the scene of the tragedy, and to examine any evidence which may have been overlooked."

"Of course, Mr. Holmes. I shall be happy to accompany you."

events.text_segment:
“I am ashamed of you, Holmes,” said Lestrade with dignity after a few minutes’ silence. “Why should you raise up hopes which you are bound to disappoint? I am not over-tender of heart, but I call it cruel.”
“I think that I see my way to clearing James McCarthy,” said Holmes. “Have you an order to see him in prison?”
“Yes, but only for you and me.”
“Then I shall reconsider my resolution about going out. We have still time to take a train to Hereford and see him to-night?”
“Ample.”
“Then let us do so. Watson, I fear that you will find it very slow, but I shall only be away a couple of hours.”
I walked down to the station with them, and then wandered through the streets of the little town, finally returning to the hotel, where I lay upon the sofa and tried to interest myself in a yellow-backed novel. The puny plot of the story was so thin, however, when compared to the deep mystery through which we were groping, and I found my attention wander so continually from the action to the fact, that I at last flung it across the room and gave myself up entirely to a consideration of the events of the day. Supposing that this unhappy young man’s story were absolutely true, then what hellish thing, what absolutely unforeseen and extraordinary calamity could have occurred between the time when he parted from his father, and the moment when, drawn back by his screams, he rushed into the glade? It was something terrible and deadly. What could it be? Might not the nature of the injuries reveal something to my medical instincts? I rang the bell and called for the weekly county paper, which contained a verbatim account of the inquest. In the surgeon’s deposition it was stated that the posterior third of the left parietal bone and the left half of the occipital bone had been shattered by a heavy blow from a blunt weapon. I marked the spot upon my own head. Clearly such a blow must have been struck from behind. That was to some extent in favour of the accused, as when seen quarrelling he was face to face with his father. Still, it did not go for very much, for the older man might have turned his back before the blow fell. Still, it might be worth while to call Holmes’ attention to it. Then there was the peculiar dying reference to a rat. What could that mean? It could not be delirium. A man dying from a sudden blow does not commonly become delirious. No, it was more likely to be an attempt to explain how he met his fate. But what could it indicate? I cudgelled my brains to find some possible explanation. And then the incident of the grey cloth seen by young McCarthy. If that were true the murderer must have dropped some part of his dress, presumably his overcoat, in his flight, and must have had the hardihood to return and to carry it away at the instant when the son was kneeling with his back turned not a dozen paces off. What a tissue of mysteries and improbabilities the whole thing was! I did not wonder at Lestrade’s opinion, and yet I had so much faith in Sherlock Holmes’ insight that I could not lose hope as long as every fresh fact seemed to strengthen his conviction of young McCarthy’s innocence.

“I am ashamed of you, Holmes,” said Lestrade with dignity after a few minutes’ silence. “Why should you be, Lestrade?” Holmes asked, his tone mild but his eyes glinting with amusement. “Because you make a mockery of the police force. You treat this investigation as if it were a game, and yet you expect us to take your word for everything.”

Holmes smiled, unperturbed. “My dear Lestrade, I assure you, I have the greatest respect for the police force. But you must admit, there are times when a little imagination is required.”

Lestrade sniffed. “Imagination is all very well, but it won’t stand up in court. We need facts, Holmes. Facts and evidence.”

“Quite so,” Holmes agreed. “And I believe you will find that the facts, when properly examined, will point in the direction I have indicated.”

Lestrade shook his head. “You’re too clever by half, Holmes. One day you’ll go too far.”

Holmes only smiled again, and turned his attention back to the small object he held in his hand. It was a curious thing, a piece of twisted metal, no larger than a coin, but with a peculiar pattern etched into its surface. He examined it closely, turning it over and over between his long, slender fingers.

Watson, who had been watching the exchange in silence, now spoke up. “Holmes, do you really believe this is the key to the whole affair?”

“I do, Watson,” Holmes replied. “It is often the smallest detail that unlocks the greatest mystery. Consider, for example, the curious incident of the dog in the night-time.”

Lestrade frowned. “What dog? There was no dog.”

“Precisely,” said Holmes, with a twinkle in his eye. “The absence of the dog’s bark is itself a fact, and a most significant one.”

Lestrade looked unconvinced, but Watson nodded thoughtfully. “I see what you mean, Holmes. Sometimes what does not happen is as important as what does.”

“Exactly, my dear Watson. Now, if you will permit me, I believe we should pay a visit to Mr. Jabez Wilson. There are one or two questions I should like to put to him.”

Lestrade sighed, but he knew better than to argue with Holmes when he was in this mood. “Very well, Holmes. Lead the way.”

The three men left the small office and made their way through the bustling streets of London. The fog was thick, and the gas lamps cast long, wavering shadows on the pavement. Holmes walked briskly, his keen eyes darting from side to side, taking in every detail.

At last they arrived at the pawnbroker’s shop. Mr. Wilson greeted them nervously, his round face pale and anxious.

“Mr. Holmes! Have you discovered anything?”

Holmes smiled reassuringly. “I believe I have, Mr. Wilson. But I must ask you a few more questions. Tell me, did you notice anything unusual about your assistant, Mr. Spaulding, in the days leading up to the incident?”

Wilson thought for a moment. “Well, now that you mention it, he did seem rather preoccupied. He was always in the cellar, you know, working on some project or other.”

“Indeed,” said Holmes. “And did you ever see what he was doing down there?”

Wilson shook his head. “No, he always said it was private business.”

Holmes nodded. “Thank you, Mr. Wilson. That will be all for now.”

As they left the shop, Lestrade turned to Holmes. “Well, Holmes? What do you make of it?”

Holmes smiled. “I think, Lestrade, that we are very close to the solution. All that remains is to catch the criminals in the act.”

It was late before Sherlock Holmes returned. He came back alone, for Lestrade was staying in lodgings in the town.
“The glass still keeps very high,” he remarked as he sat down. “It is of importance that it should not rain before we are able to go over the ground. On the other hand, a man should be at his very best and keenest for such nice work as that, and I did not wish to do it when fagged by a long journey. I have seen young McCarthy.”
“And what did you learn from him?”
“Nothing.”
“Could he throw no light?”
“None at all. I was inclined to think at one time that he knew who had done it and was screening him or her, but I am convinced now that he is as puzzled as everyone else. He is not a very quick-witted youth, though comely to look at and, I should think, sound at heart.”
“I cannot admire his taste,” I remarked, “if it is indeed a fact that he was averse to a marriage with so charming a young lady as this Miss Turner.”
“Ah, thereby hangs a rather painful tale. This fellow is madly, insanely, in love with her, but some two years ago, when he was only a lad, and before he really knew her, for she had been away five years at a boarding-school, what does the idiot do but get into the clutches of a barmaid in Bristol and marry her at a registry office? No one knows a word of the matter, but you can imagine how maddening it must be to him to be upbraided for not doing what he would give his very eyes to do, but what he knows to be absolutely impossible. It was sheer frenzy of this sort which made him throw his hands up into the air when his father, at their last interview, was goading him on to propose to Miss Turner. On the other hand, he had no means of supporting himself, and his father, who was by all accounts a very hard man, would have thrown him over utterly had he known the truth. It was with his barmaid wife that he had spent the last three days in Bristol, and his father did not know where he was. Mark that point. It is of importance. Good has come out of evil, however, for the barmaid, finding from the papers that he is in serious trouble and likely to be hanged, has thrown him over utterly and has written to him to say that she has a husband already in the Bermuda Dockyard, so that there is really no tie between them. I think that that bit of news has consoled young McCarthy for all that he has suffered.”
“But if he is innocent, who has done it?”
“Ah! who? I would call your attention very particularly to two points. One is that the murdered man had an appointment with someone at the pool, and that the someone could not have been his son, for his son was away, and he did not know when he would return. The second is that the murdered man was heard to cry ‘Cooee!’ before he knew that his son had returned. Those are the crucial points upon which the case depends. And now let us talk about George Meredith, if you please, and we shall leave all minor matters until to-morrow.”

"Yes, Watson. I have been to Brixton Road, and I have made some progress. The case is a singular one, and I confess that it has presented more difficulties than I anticipated. But I think we are on the right scent now."

He threw himself into a chair and stretched his long legs out before him. For a few moments he was silent, his eyes fixed on the glowing embers in the grate. Then he turned to me with a sudden energy.

"You remember the details of the case, Watson?"

"Perfectly. The murdered man, Enoch Drebber, was found in an empty house in Brixton Road. There were no signs of robbery, and the word 'RACHE' was written in blood upon the wall."

"Exactly. And what do you make of it?"

I hesitated. "It is a most mysterious affair. The writing on the wall seems to point to some secret society, perhaps something German."

Holmes smiled. "That is the obvious conclusion, and yet I am not satisfied. There are other factors to be considered. For instance, the ring which was found at the scene."

"The wedding ring?"

"Yes. It is a woman's ring, and it is of some importance. I have made inquiries, and I believe I have traced its owner."

"Indeed! That is a step forward."

"It is. But there is more. I have also discovered that Drebber was being followed on the night of his death."

"By whom?"

"That is what I am trying to ascertain. I have a theory, but I need more evidence."

He rose and began to pace the room, his hands clasped behind his back.

"The case is complicated by the presence of Drebber's companion, Joseph Stangerson. He has disappeared, and the police are searching for him."

"It is possible. But I am not convinced. There are too many unexplained details. For example, the manner in which Drebber was killed. There was no wound, no sign of violence, and yet he is dead."

detailed_summary: The next morning is clear, as Holmes predicted.
Lestrade arrives with a carriage at 9 AM.
Lestrade shares news that Mr. Turner is critically ill.
Holmes inquires about Turner's age (around sixty) and learns his health has been poor due to his life abroad, and McCarthy's death worsened his condition.
Lestrade reveals Turner was a great benefactor to McCarthy, even giving him Hatherley Farm rent-free and helping in many other ways.
Holmes finds it peculiar that McCarthy, so indebted to Turner, would push for his son to marry Turner's heiress daughter, especially since Turner himself opposed the match.
Lestrade dismisses Holmes's 'deductions and inferences,' preferring 'facts.'
Holmes retorts that Lestrade finds tackling facts hard.
Lestrade insists the fact is McCarthy Jr. killed McCarthy Sr.
Holmes compares Lestrade's certainty to 'fog' and his own theories to 'moonshine,' then identifies Hatherley Farm.
At the farm, Holmes examines the boots worn by McCarthy Sr. at death and a pair of his son's boots, taking careful measurements.
They follow the path to Boscombe Pool.
Holmes transforms into an intensely focused investigator, his demeanor becoming predatory and concentrated.
He moves swiftly along the path, examining the damp ground, occasionally stopping or making detours, ignoring questions.
At Boscombe Pool, Lestrade points out the body's location, where traces are still visible.
Holmes intently reads many more details from the trampled grass.
He questions Lestrade about disturbing the pool bed with a rake.
Holmes identifies Lestrade's footprints and complains about the scene being trampled.
He identifies three sets of tracks belonging to James McCarthy (walking twice, running once), confirming his story.
He finds the father's footprints and marks from the gun butt where James stood.
He discovers unusual, square-toed boot prints ('Tiptoes!') coming and going, deducing this was for retrieving the dropped cloak.
Following these tracks into the woods under a large beech tree, Holmes examines the ground, leaves, bark, and collects dust.
He finds a jagged stone among the moss, examines it carefully, and keeps it.
He follows the tracks to the high road where they disappear.
Returning to his normal manner, Holmes states the case is interesting and decides to speak with Moran at the lodge before returning for lunch.

events.text_segment:
There was no rain, as Holmes had foretold, and the morning broke bright and cloudless. At nine o’clock Lestrade called for us with the carriage, and we set off for Hatherley Farm and the Boscombe Pool.
“There is serious news this morning,” Lestrade observed. “It is said that Mr. Turner, of the Hall, is so ill that his life is despaired of.”
“An elderly man, I presume?” said Holmes.
“About sixty; but his constitution has been shattered by his life abroad, and he has been in failing health for some time. This business has had a very bad effect upon him. He was an old friend of McCarthy’s, and, I may add, a great benefactor to him, for I have learned that he gave him Hatherley Farm rent free.”
“Indeed! That is interesting,” said Holmes.
“Oh, yes! In a hundred other ways he has helped him. Everybody about here speaks of his kindness to him.”
“Really! Does it not strike you as a little singular that this McCarthy, who appears to have had little of his own, and to have been under such obligations to Turner, should still talk of marrying his son to Turner’s daughter, who is, presumably, heiress to the estate, and that in such a very cocksure manner, as if it were merely a case of a proposal and all else would follow? It is the more strange, since we know that Turner himself was averse to the idea. The daughter told us as much. Do you not deduce something from that?”
“We have got to the deductions and the inferences,” said Lestrade, winking at me. “I find it hard enough to tackle facts, Holmes, without flying away after theories and fancies.”
“You are right,” said Holmes demurely; “you do find it very hard to tackle the facts.”
“Anyhow, I have grasped one fact which you seem to find it difficult to get hold of,” replied Lestrade with some warmth.
“And that is—”
“That McCarthy senior met his death from McCarthy junior and that all theories to the contrary are the merest moonshine.”
“Well, moonshine is a brighter thing than fog,” said Holmes, laughing. “But I am very much mistaken if this is not Hatherley Farm upon the left.”
“Yes, that is it.” It was a widespread, comfortable-looking building, two-storied, slate-roofed, with great yellow blotches of lichen upon the grey walls. The drawn blinds and the smokeless chimneys, however, gave it a stricken look, as though the weight of this horror still lay heavy upon it. We called at the door, when the maid, at Holmes’ request, showed us the boots which her master wore at the time of his death, and also a pair of the son’s, though not the pair which he had then had. Having measured these very carefully from seven or eight different points, Holmes desired to be led to the court-yard, from which we all followed the winding track which led to Boscombe Pool.
Sherlock Holmes was transformed when he was hot upon such a scent as this. Men who had only known the quiet thinker and logician of Baker Street would have failed to recognise him. His face flushed and darkened. His brows were drawn into two hard black lines, while his eyes shone out from beneath them with a steely glitter. His face was bent downward, his shoulders bowed, his lips compressed, and the veins stood out like whipcord in his long, sinewy neck. His nostrils seemed to dilate with a purely animal lust for the chase, and his mind was so absolutely concentrated upon the matter before him that a question or remark fell unheeded upon his ears, or, at the most, only provoked a quick, impatient snarl in reply. Swiftly and silently he made his way along the track which ran through the meadows, and so by way of the woods to the Boscombe Pool. It was damp, marshy ground, as is all that district, and there were marks of many feet, both upon the path and amid the short grass which bounded it on either side. Sometimes Holmes would hurry on, sometimes stop dead, and once he made quite a little detour into the meadow. Lestrade and I walked behind him, the detective indifferent and contemptuous, while I watched my friend with the interest which sprang from the conviction that every one of his actions was directed towards a definite end.
The Boscombe Pool, which is a little reed-girt sheet of water some fifty yards across, is situated at the boundary between the Hatherley Farm and the private park of the wealthy Mr. Turner. Above the woods which lined it upon the farther side we could see the red, jutting pinnacles which marked the site of the rich landowner’s dwelling. On the Hatherley side of the pool the woods grew very thick, and there was a narrow belt of sodden grass twenty paces across between the edge of the trees and the reeds which lined the lake. Lestrade showed us the exact spot at which the body had been found, and, indeed, so moist was the ground, that I could plainly see the traces which had been left by the fall of the stricken man. To Holmes, as I could see by his eager face and peering eyes, very many other things were to be read upon the trampled grass. He ran round, like a dog who is picking up a scent, and then turned upon my companion.
“What did you go into the pool for?” he asked.
“I fished about with a rake. I thought there might be some weapon or other trace. But how on earth—”
“Oh, tut, tut! I have no time! That left foot of yours with its inward twist is all over the place. A mole could trace it, and there it vanishes among the reeds. Oh, how simple it would all have been had I been here before they came like a herd of buffalo and wallowed all over it. Here is where the party with the lodge-keeper came, and they have covered all tracks for six or eight feet round the body. But here are three separate tracks of the same feet.” He drew out a lens and lay down upon his waterproof to have a better view, talking all the time rather to himself than to us. “These are young McCarthy’s feet. Twice he was walking, and once he ran swiftly, so that the soles are deeply marked and the heels hardly visible. That bears out his story. He ran when he saw his father on the ground. Then here are the father’s feet as he paced up and down. What is this, then? It is the butt-end of the gun as the son stood listening. And this? Ha, ha! What have we here? Tiptoes! tiptoes! Square, too, quite unusual boots! They come, they go, they come again—of course that was for the cloak. Now where did they come from?” He ran up and down, sometimes losing, sometimes finding the track until we were well within the edge of the wood and under the shadow of a great beech, the largest tree in the neighbourhood. Holmes traced his way to the farther side of this and lay down once more upon his face with a little cry of satisfaction. For a long time he remained there, turning over the leaves and dried sticks, gathering up what seemed to me to be dust into an envelope and examining with his lens not only the ground but even the bark of the tree as far as he could reach. A jagged stone was lying among the moss, and this also he carefully examined and retained. Then he followed a pathway through the wood until he came to the high road, where all traces were lost.
“It has been a case of considerable interest,” he remarked, returning to his natural manner. “I fancy that this grey house on the right must be the lodge. I think that I will go in and have a word with Moran, and perhaps write a little note. Having done that, we may drive back to our luncheon. You may walk to the cab, and I shall be with you presently.”

There was no rain, as Holmes had foretold, and the morning broke bright and cloudless. At nine o’clock Lestrade called for us with the carriage, and we set off for Hatherley Farm and the Boscombe Pool. 

“There is serious news this morning,” Lestrade observed. “Mr. Turner is so ill that his doctor fears he may not live. He was an old friend of McCarthy’s, and, I may add, a great benefactor to him, for I have learned that he gave him Hatherley Farm rent free.”

“Indeed! That is interesting,” said Holmes.

“Oh, yes! In a hundred other ways he has helped him. Everybody about here speaks of his kindness to him.”

“Yet, I suppose, that McCarthy was none the less anxious to get his son married to Miss Turner, and that he pressed the matter on more than one occasion?”

“Yes, he did,” said Lestrade. “I have learned that from several sources. But, however that may be, I think that the facts are pretty clear as they stand.”

“And yet, for all that, the case is not clear to me,” said Holmes.

“The fact is,” remarked Lestrade, “that you are like a dog with a bone. You will not let it go.”

“Now, Mr. Lestrade, I really have no time for this. I have to be at the farm by ten o’clock, and I want to have a look at the boots which McCarthy wore and at his son’s boots as well.”

We drove to the farm, and Holmes made a very careful examination of the boots, measuring them with the tape which he always carried. Then we set off along the path to the Boscombe Pool. Holmes was transformed when he was hot upon such a scent as this. He was so swift, silent, and furtive in his movements, like a bloodhound picking out a scent, that I could not but think what a terrible criminal he would have made had he turned his energy and sagacity against the law instead of exerting them in its defence. He ran up and down, sometimes stopping, sometimes whirling round, sometimes crouching as if to engage in a wrestling match with the ground, with his long, thin nose only a few inches from the surface, and his keen, grey eyes darting to right and left. The rest of us stood watching him in silence, for we had no part in what he was doing. The Maid had come up with us, and she stood with her hands clasped, watching the strange proceedings.

At the edge of the pool Lestrade pointed out the exact spot where the body had been found, and Holmes, after a long and minute examination, began to walk slowly round the edge of the water. He stopped once or twice and made a few notes in his notebook. Then he turned to Lestrade.

“Did you, by any chance, move the body before the police arrived?”

“No, I waited until they came.”

“Did you see any marks on the ground?”

“Nothing of any importance.”

“I am afraid there are a good many marks of boots about here,” he said, “but since the police have been here, there have probably been a good many people on the ground.”

“Yes, there are a good many tracks,” Lestrade admitted. “But I think that we can disregard all the footprints of those who came after the police.”

Holmes gave a little cry of satisfaction, and, bending down, he examined the ground with his lens. “This is quite a pretty demonstration,” he said. “There are three sets of tracks clearly marked. One is the track of McCarthy himself, going to the pool. The second is that of his son, coming and going. The third is a peculiar one, with square-toed boots. I have seen the same tracks at the hall door. Now, Watson, let us see who else has been here.”

He ran along, stooping and peering, and then turned suddenly into the wood. “Here are the tracks again,” he said, pointing to the ground. “He seems to have come in this direction.”

He followed the path through the wood, and then, under a great beech tree, he stopped and examined the ground and the bark of the tree. “I have seen all I wish,” said he. “Now we can go back to the house.”

“By the way, Lestrade,” he added, as we walked back, “I suppose you have no objection to my having a look at the stone which struck McCarthy?”

“Not at all. It is in the office.”

“Show me to it.”

We went together to the office, and Holmes examined the jagged stone with great attention. “Thank you,” said he. “May I keep this stone for a little?”

“Certainly.”

“Come, Watson, I think that we have done all that we can here. I would like to have a word with Moran at the lodge before we go back to lunch.”

Everywhere the birds were singing, and there was a cheerfulness in the air which set the last seal upon the nature of a perfect English spring day. Holmes and I had breakfasted, and he was already deep in the study of the morning papers, when a knock sounded at the door. It was our client, Miss Mary Sutherland, who had come to hear the result of our investigations. She was looking pale and anxious, and her eyes were red with weeping.

"Good-morning, Miss Sutherland," said Holmes, rising and bowing with that easy courtesy for which he was remarkable. "Pray take a seat. Have you any news for us?"

"No, Mr. Holmes; I have heard nothing since I saw you last."

"I have some news for you, then. I have solved your case."

Miss Sutherland started and looked at him with an expression of mingled hope and fear. "You have found him?" she gasped.

"Yes, I have found him."

"Oh, Mr. Holmes, can you bring him back to me?"

"I am afraid that is quite out of the question."

"But why should he have done this cruel thing?"

"Because he loved you, Miss Sutherland. If he had not loved you, he would not have run away."

She looked at him in bewilderment. "I do not understand."

Holmes leaned forward and laid his long, thin fingers together. "It is a very simple case, Miss Sutherland, very simple indeed. You will excuse me for not taking you into my confidence earlier, but I feared that I might raise hopes which could never be realized."

"But how did you find out?"

"I have my own methods. But let us go over the facts once more. Your stepfather, Mr. Windibank, objected to your marriage with Mr. Hosmer Angel. He was a man of strong character, and he had his own reasons for wishing you to remain at home."

"Yes, he always said that he could not bear to part with me."

"Exactly. Now, when Mr. Hosmer Angel appeared upon the scene, your stepfather was away in France. He returned, and at once Mr. Angel disappeared."

"Yes, but I do not see—"

"You do not see because you are not looking in the right direction. The person who disappeared was not Mr. Hosmer Angel, but Mr. Windibank himself."

She stared at him in amazement. "But Mr. Windibank was at home."

"He was at home, but he was also Mr. Hosmer Angel. It was a clever disguise, but not clever enough. The glasses, the whiskers, the voice—all were intended to mislead you. But I saw through it from the first."

Miss Sutherland sank back in her chair, her hands clasped together. "Oh, it is impossible!" she cried. "It cannot be!"

"It is true, nevertheless. I have written to Mr. Windibank, and I have no doubt that he will confirm what I say."

There was a silence, broken only by the ticking of the clock upon the mantelpiece. At last Miss Sutherland rose and took her leave, her face pale but resolute. Holmes watched her go with a look of mingled pity and admiration.

"She will be all right," he said, turning to me. "There is a spirit in that woman which will carry her through anything. She will never marry now, for she has had her heart broken, but she will be a better woman for it."

I could not but admire the way in which Holmes had unravelled the tangled skein of this strange case. It was a triumph of his peculiar method, and I felt that I had been privileged to witness a master at work.

As we sat together in the quiet of our rooms, I could not help but reflect upon the curious nature of human affairs, and the strange twists and turns which fate can take. Holmes, for his part, seemed content to let the matter rest, and soon turned his attention to other cases which demanded his unique talents.

Thus ended the case of the disappearing bridegroom, one of the most singular and interesting of all the adventures which I have had the privilege of sharing with my remarkable friend, Sherlock Holmes.

events.title: Revealing the Murder Weapon and Killer Profile
detailed_summary: Returning to Ross in the cab, Holmes presents the stone to Lestrade.
He declares it the murder weapon.
Lestrade sees no marks, but Holmes explains the grass growing under it showed it was recently placed there, no source was nearby, and it matched the injuries, with no other weapon found.
Holmes describes the murderer: tall, left-handed, limps with the right leg, wears thick-soled shooting boots and a grey cloak, smokes Indian cigars using a holder, and carries a blunt pen-knife.
Lestrade remains skeptical, prioritizing hard evidence for a jury over Holmes's theories.
Holmes calmly states they will see ('Nous verrons') and that he will work his way while Lestrade works his.
Holmes announces he'll be busy that afternoon and likely return to London that evening, claiming the case is finished and solved.
He identifies the criminal only as 'The gentleman I describe,' suggesting Lestrade should be able to find him in the sparsely populated area.
Lestrade dismisses the task of finding a left-handed man with a limp as impractical and likely to make him a laughing-stock.
Holmes quietly accepts Lestrade's refusal, drops him at his lodgings, and says he'll send a note before leaving.
Back at the hotel, Holmes is silent and thoughtful during lunch, appearing perplexed.
After the meal, Holmes asks Watson to listen as he needs advice and wants to explain his reasoning.

events.text_segment:
It was about ten minutes before we regained our cab and drove back into Ross, Holmes still carrying with him the stone which he had picked up in the wood.
“This may interest you, Lestrade,” he remarked, holding it out. “The murder was done with it.”
“I see no marks.”
“There are none.”
“How do you know, then?”
“The grass was growing under it. It had only lain there a few days. There was no sign of a place whence it had been taken. It corresponds with the injuries. There is no sign of any other weapon.”
“And the murderer?”
“Is a tall man, left-handed, limps with the right leg, wears thick-soled shooting-boots and a grey cloak, smokes Indian cigars, uses a cigar-holder, and carries a blunt pen-knife in his pocket. There are several other indications, but these may be enough to aid us in our search.”
Lestrade laughed. “I am afraid that I am still a sceptic,” he said. “Theories are all very well, but we have to deal with a hard-headed British jury.”
“Nous verrons,” answered Holmes calmly. “You work your own method, and I shall work mine. I shall be busy this afternoon, and shall probably return to London by the evening train.”
“And leave your case unfinished?”
“No, finished.”
“But the mystery?”
“It is solved.”
“Who was the criminal, then?”
“The gentleman I describe.”
“But who is he?”
“Surely it would not be difficult to find out. This is not such a populous neighbourhood.”
Lestrade shrugged his shoulders. “I am a practical man,” he said, “and I really cannot undertake to go about the country looking for a left-handed gentleman with a game leg. I should become the laughing-stock of Scotland Yard.”
“All right,” said Holmes quietly. “I have given you the chance. Here are your lodgings. Good-bye. I shall drop you a line before I leave.”
Having left Lestrade at his rooms, we drove to our hotel, where we found lunch upon the table. Holmes was silent and buried in thought with a pained expression upon his face, as one who finds himself in a perplexing position.
“Look here, Watson,” he said when the cloth was cleared “just sit down in this chair and let me preach to you for a little. I don’t know quite what to do, and I should value your advice. Light a cigar and let me expound.”

“Is a tall man, left-handed, limps with the right leg, wears thick-soled shooting boots and a grey cloak, smokes Indian cigars, uses a cigar-holder, and carries a blunt penknife in his pocket. There are several other indications, but these may be enough to aid us in our search.”

Lestrade laughed. “I am afraid that I am still a sceptic,” he said. “Theories are all very well, but we have to deal with a hard-headed British jury.”

“Nous verrons,” answered Holmes calmly. “You work your own method, and I shall work mine. I shall be busy this afternoon, and shall probably return to London by the evening train.”

“And leave your case unfinished?”

“No, finished.”

“But the mystery?”

“It is solved.”

“Who was the criminal, then?”

“The gentleman I describe.”

“But who is he?”

“Surely it would not be difficult to find out. This is not such a populous neighbourhood.”

Lestrade shrugged his shoulders. “I am a practical man,” he said, “and I really cannot undertake to go about the country looking for a left-handed gentleman with a game leg. I should become the laughing-stock of Scotland Yard.”

“All right,” said Holmes quietly. “I have given you the chance. Here are your lodgings. Good-bye. I shall send a line before I leave.”

Having left Lestrade at his rooms, we drove to our hotel, where we found lunch upon the table. Holmes was silent and moody during the meal. From time to time the look of a man who is lost in thought and yet has a certain perplexity upon his face came over him. When the cloth was cleared, he took an envelope from his pocket and laid it upon the table.

“Watson,” said he, “if you can spare the time, I should be very glad of a little help. I want you to be with me in my reasoning. Listen to me, and let me know what you think.”

“Pray do so.”
“Well, now, in considering this case there are two points about young McCarthy’s narrative which struck us both instantly, although they impressed me in his favour and you against him. One was the fact that his father should, according to his account, cry ‘Cooee!’ before seeing him. The other was his singular dying reference to a rat. He mumbled several words, you understand, but that was all that caught the son’s ear. Now from this double point our research must commence, and we will begin it by presuming that what the lad says is absolutely true.”
“What of this ‘Cooee!’ then?”
“Well, obviously it could not have been meant for the son. The son, as far as he knew, was in Bristol. It was mere chance that he was within earshot. The ‘Cooee!’ was meant to attract the attention of whoever it was that he had the appointment with. But ‘Cooee’ is a distinctly Australian cry, and one which is used between Australians. There is a strong presumption that the person whom McCarthy expected to meet him at Boscombe Pool was someone who had been in Australia.”
“What of the rat, then?”
Sherlock Holmes took a folded paper from his pocket and flattened it out on the table. “This is a map of the Colony of Victoria,” he said. “I wired to Bristol for it last night.” He put his hand over part of the map. “What do you read?”
“ARAT,” I read.
“And now?” He raised his hand.
“BALLARAT.”
“Quite so. That was the word the man uttered, and of which his son only caught the last two syllables. He was trying to utter the name of his murderer. So and so, of Ballarat.”

“Now, Watson, let us have a little light upon this. The case is not entirely devoid of interest. I cannot doubt that we are approaching the solution. You have heard the facts. What do you make of them?”

“I have none. I cannot recall any case within my experience which looked at the first glance so simple and yet which presented such difficulties.”

“I am afraid my own judgment is somewhat clouded by my sympathy for young McCarthy. I am afraid that I am unwittingly biased in his favour. I will state the case clearly and fairly to you, however, and you shall form your own judgment.”

He recapitulated the facts as they had been brought out before the coroner. “What is your own theory?” he asked.

“I have none. I have not yet been able to form one. I have no doubt at all as to the young man’s guilt. That is, of course, presuming that the facts are as stated. I have no doubt that he met his father, that there was a quarrel, that the son struck the father and that the father died. But beyond this I can see nothing.”

“And yet there are two points in young McCarthy’s narrative which struck us both. One was the fact that his father should cry ‘Cooee!’ before seeing his son. The other was his dying reference to a rat.”

He laughed at my puzzled expression. “You recall, of course, the singular dying reference to a rat. But let us take the first point first. His father had an appointment at the pool, and yet, when he reached there, he cried out ‘Cooee!’ which is a distinctly Australian cry, and one which is used between Australians. The call was not intended for his son, for his son was not expected there. It was intended for the person with whom he had an appointment.”

“But he had no appointment,” I said.

“The evidence shows that he had. He had received a note from someone who, in the guise of business, had asked him to come to the pool at a certain hour. Who could this be but the person who met him and who afterwards killed him? The call of ‘Cooee!’ was heard by several witnesses. If it was not meant for his son, it must have been meant for the person with whom he was meeting. But ‘Cooee!’ is a distinctly Australian cry, and one which is used between Australians. The person, therefore, whom McCarthy expected to meet at the pool was someone who had been in Australia.”

“What of the rat, then?” I asked.

Sherlock Holmes took a folded paper from his pocket and flattened it out on the table. “This is a map of the Colony of Victoria,” he said. “I wired to Bristol for it last night.” He put his hand over part of the map. “What do you read?”

“ARAT,” I read.

“And now?” He raised his hand.

“BALLARAT.”

“It is the name of a city in Victoria. The dying man was trying to indicate the name of his murderer. So far as he could, he wrote it. He was trying to say ‘Ballarat.’”

“You are sure?”

“Absolutely. The case is as clear as daylight. The evidence is all in favour of young McCarthy, and the only person who could possibly have committed the crime is the man who was known to have been in Australia, who was known to have been at Ballarat, and who was known to have worn a grey cloak. That is the man who killed Mr. McCarthy.”

“But how did you arrive at these conclusions?”

“By observing trifles. The length of the stride, the impression of the boot, the peculiar shape of the heel, the fact that the right foot was always less distinct than the left, showing that the man was lame. The blow was struck from behind and upon the left side, showing that the assailant was left-handed. The cigar ash which I found behind the tree, Indian cigar ash, and the cigar itself, which was rolled in Rotterdam, and which had not been bitten, but cut with a blunt penknife. All these things point to the same man. And now, Watson, if you will excuse me, I think we shall have news of Mr. John Turner.”

As he spoke, the door opened, and the waiter announced Mr. John Turner.

The man who entered was a strange and impressive figure. His slow, limping step and bowed shoulders gave the appearance of decrepitude, and yet his hard, deep-lined, craggy features, and his enormous limbs showed that he was possessed of unusual strength of body and of character. His tangled beard, grizzled hair, and outstanding, drooping eyebrows combined to give an air of dignity and power to his appearance, but his face was of an ashen white, while his lips and the corners of his nostrils were tinged with a shade of blue. It was clear to me at a glance that he was in the grip of some deadly and chronic disease.
“Pray sit down on the sofa,” said Holmes gently. “You had my note?”
“Yes, the lodge-keeper brought it up. You said that you wished to see me here to avoid scandal.”
“I thought people would talk if I went to the Hall.”
“And why did you wish to see me?” He looked across at my companion with despair in his weary eyes, as though his question was already answered.
“Yes,” said Holmes, answering the look rather than the words. “It is so. I know all about McCarthy.”
The old man sank his face in his hands. “God help me!” he cried. “But I would not have let the young man come to harm. I give you my word that I would have spoken out if it went against him at the Assizes.”
“I am glad to hear you say so,” said Holmes gravely.
“I would have spoken now had it not been for my dear girl. It would break her heart—it will break her heart when she hears that I am arrested.”
“It may not come to that,” said Holmes.
“What?”
“I am no official agent. I understand that it was your daughter who required my presence here, and I am acting in her interests. Young McCarthy must be got off, however.”
“I am a dying man,” said old Turner. “I have had diabetes for years. My doctor says it is a question whether I shall live a month. Yet I would rather die under my own roof than in a gaol.”
Holmes rose and sat down at the table with his pen in his hand and a bundle of paper before him. “Just tell us the truth,” he said. “I shall jot down the facts. You will sign it, and Watson here can witness it. Then I could produce your confession at the last extremity to save young McCarthy. I promise you that I shall not use it unless it is absolutely needed.”
“It’s as well,” said the old man; “it’s a question whether I shall live to the Assizes, so it matters little to me, but I should wish to spare Alice the shock. And now I will make the thing clear to you; it has been a long time in the acting, but will not take me long to tell.
“You didn’t know this dead man, McCarthy. He was a devil incarnate. I tell you that. God keep you out of the clutches of such a man as he. His grip has been upon me these twenty years, and he has blasted my life. I’ll tell you first how I came to be in his power.
“It was in the early ’60’s at the diggings. I was a young chap then, hot-blooded and reckless, ready to turn my hand at anything; I got among bad companions, took to drink, had no luck with my claim, took to the bush, and in a word became what you would call over here a highway robber. There were six of us, and we had a wild, free life of it, sticking up a station from time to time, or stopping the wagons on the road to the diggings. Black Jack of Ballarat was the name I went under, and our party is still remembered in the colony as the Ballarat Gang.
“One day a gold convoy came down from Ballarat to Melbourne, and we lay in wait for it and attacked it. There were six troopers and six of us, so it was a close thing, but we emptied four of their saddles at the first volley. Three of our boys were killed, however, before we got the swag. I put my pistol to the head of the wagon-driver, who was this very man McCarthy. I wish to the Lord that I had shot him then, but I spared him, though I saw his wicked little eyes fixed on my face, as though to remember every feature. We got away with the gold, became wealthy men, and made our way over to England without being suspected. There I parted from my old pals and determined to settle down to a quiet and respectable life. I bought this estate, which chanced to be in the market, and I set myself to do a little good with my money, to make up for the way in which I had earned it. I married, too, and though my wife died young she left me my dear little Alice. Even when she was just a baby her wee hand seemed to lead me down the right path as nothing else had ever done. In a word, I turned over a new leaf and did my best to make up for the past. All was going well when McCarthy laid his grip upon me.
“I had gone up to town about an investment, and I met him in Regent Street with hardly a coat to his back or a boot to his foot.
“‘Here we are, Jack,’ says he, touching me on the arm; ‘we’ll be as good as a family to you. There’s two of us, me and my son, and you can have the keeping of us. If you don’t—it’s a fine, law-abiding country is England, and there’s always a policeman within hail.’
“Well, down they came to the west country, there was no shaking them off, and there they have lived rent free on my best land ever since. There was no rest for me, no peace, no forgetfulness; turn where I would, there was his cunning, grinning face at my elbow. It grew worse as Alice grew up, for he soon saw I was more afraid of her knowing my past than of the police. Whatever he wanted he must have, and whatever it was I gave him without question, land, money, houses, until at last he asked a thing which I could not give. He asked for Alice.
“His son, you see, had grown up, and so had my girl, and as I was known to be in weak health, it seemed a fine stroke to him that his lad should step into the whole property. But there I was firm. I would not have his cursed stock mixed with mine; not that I had any dislike to the lad, but his blood was in him, and that was enough. I stood firm. McCarthy threatened. I braved him to do his worst. We were to meet at the pool midway between our houses to talk it over.
“When I went down there I found him talking with his son, so I smoked a cigar and waited behind a tree until he should be alone. But as I listened to his talk all that was black and bitter in me seemed to come uppermost. He was urging his son to marry my daughter with as little regard for what she might think as if she were a slut from off the streets. It drove me mad to think that I and all that I held most dear should be in the power of such a man as this. Could I not snap the bond? I was already a dying and a desperate man. Though clear of mind and fairly strong of limb, I knew that my own fate was sealed. But my memory and my girl! Both could be saved if I could but silence that foul tongue. I did it, Mr. Holmes. I would do it again. Deeply as I have sinned, I have led a life of martyrdom to atone for it. But that my girl should be entangled in the same meshes which held me was more than I could suffer. I struck him down with no more compunction than if he had been some foul and venomous beast. His cry brought back his son; but I had gained the cover of the wood, though I was forced to go back to fetch the cloak which I had dropped in my flight. That is the true story, gentlemen, of all that occurred.”

His tawny beard, grizzled with age, was cut square and ended in a broad, massive chin. His deep-set, bile-shot eyes, and the high, thin fleshless nose, gave him somewhat the resemblance to a fierce old bird of prey.

He looked at us in silence for a moment; then, with a swift, furtive glance at the door, he came forward and seated himself.

"Mr. Holmes?" he asked.

My companion bowed.

"I received your note, Mr. Holmes. I came to the hotel at once. I heard that you had been down to the scene of the tragedy."

"Yes," said Holmes; "I have seen everything which I could see."

"I have been closely questioned by the police, but they seem to have no evidence. I hope that you have formed a definite opinion?"

"I have."

"May I ask what it is?"

"It is that you are not the murderer."

He started violently, and his face turned ashen grey. A terrible convulsion passed over it, and he clutched the sides of the chair with his bony hands.

"What do you mean?" he gasped. "Who, then, is the murderer?"

"I was hoping that you could tell me."

He groaned and sank his face in his hands. "God help me! God help me!" he muttered; but I would have confessed had it not been for my girl. If it were not for her, I would have gone to the police and told them everything."

"It was to save her from sorrow that you concealed the truth?"

"Yes, yes, it was to save her."

"But you must see that if her son is convicted, or her lover, it will be a far greater blow to her than if you yourself were arrested."

"God knows it would. But I could not bear to see her heart broken."

"You are the last man in the world whom I would wish to injure," said Holmes. "But I must use every means at my disposal to clear this young man, and you know that I will not hesitate to use your confession if it should prove necessary."

"You are right. I will give it to you now. I am a dying man. I have but a month to live. I am dying of diabetes, and I have not the strength to resist you. I will tell you all."

He leaned back in his chair, and began his story in a low, broken voice.

"It is as well," he said. "You have been very kind to me, Mr. Holmes. I will tell you the truth. I was a wild and reckless youth in Australia, a member of the Ballarat gang. I was known as Black Jack of Ballarat. We attacked a gold convoy, and I held a pistol to the driver’s head. That driver was McCarthy. I spared his life, but he recognized me. We escaped with the gold, and I returned to England, bought my estate, and tried to live a respectable life. I married, and my daughter Alice was born. I thought I had left my past behind me.

"Years later, McCarthy turned up in London, penniless. He recognized me, and from that day he held my life in his hands.
